artefact.overview: You may need to tell DVLA if you've had an intracerebral haemorrhage - if you do, download the correct form to let them know
artefact.body:
You may need to tell DVLA if you’ve had an intracerebral haemorrhage.

You can be fined up to £1,000 if you don’t tell DVLA about a medical condition that affects your driving. If you’re involved in an accident, you may be prosecuted.

Car or motorcycle licence

You only need to tell DVLA if you’re still having problems a month after an intracerebral haemorrhage. If you are, fill in form STR1 and send it to DVLA. The address is on the form.

Download ‘STR1 - Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 298KB)

Download information leaflet ‘TIA1’ for more information on driving after a stroke or transient ischaemic attack.

Download form ‘TIA1 - Car or motorcycle drivers who have had a stroke or transient ischaemic attack’ (PDF, 260KB)

Bus, coach or lorry licence

You’ll must tell DVLA. Fill in form STR1V and send to the address on the form.

Download ‘STR1V - Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 315KB)
